headline: Greta: Dems, GOP reveal phoniness in 'nuke' option battle
subHeadline: Greta's 'Off the Record', 11/21/13: Both parties show hypocrisy by flip-flopping over the so-called 'nuclear option.'

utterances.speaker: SENATOR BARACK OBAMA
utterances.sentences: That the majority chooses to end the filibuster, if they choose to change the rules and put an end to democratic debate, then the fighting and the bitterness and the gridlock will only get worse. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('tablet', 'lb3', 'tablet-tw-ad-lb3', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } Now, that's 180 degrees different from what President Obama said today. Today, he likes the idea of a nuclear option. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('mobile', 'ban3', 'mobile-mw-ad-ban3', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.sentences: So, I support the step a majority of senators today took to change the way that Washington is doing business. Other Democratic leaders weren't keen on the nuclear option back in 2005, either.

utterances.speaker: SENATOR HARRY REID, MAJORITY LEADER
utterances.sentences: The filibuster is far from a procedural gimmick. It's part of the fabric of this institution we call the Senate. Some in this chamber want to throw out 214 years of Senate history in the quest for absolute power. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('tablet', 'lb5', 'tablet-tw-ad-lb5', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('mobile', 'ban5', 'mobile-mw-ad-ban5', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: SENATOR JOE BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I say to my friends on the republican side you may own the field right now, but you won't own it forever. And I pray God when the Democrats take back control we don't make the kind of naked power grab you are doing. utterances.speaker: I will get to my point first. I will get to my point in a minute, but first this
utterances.utterance: Remember this 2005 video, when Republican senators tried the same move, the same stunt, to invoke the nuclear option? Democrats went wild with rage, even accusing the Republicans of a quest for absolute power. Here is then-Senator Obama leading the charge:

utterances.speaker: SENATOR BARACK OBAMA
utterances.utterance: That the majority chooses to end the filibuster, if they choose to change the rules and put an end to democratic debate, then the fighting and the bitterness and the gridlock will only get worse. Now, that's 180 degrees different from what President Obama said today. Today, he likes the idea of a nuclear option.

utterances.speaker: BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: So, I support the step a majority of senators today took to change the way that Washington is doing business. More specifically, the way the senate does business. And President Obama is not the only one changing his tune. Other Democratic leaders weren't keen on the nuclear option back in 2005, either.

utterances.speaker: SENATOR HARRY REID, MAJORITY LEADER
utterances.utterance: The filibuster is far from a procedural gimmick. It's part of the fabric of this institution we call the Senate. Some in this chamber want to throw out 214 years of Senate history in the quest for absolute power.

utterances.speaker: SENATOR JOE BIDEN
utterances.utterance: I say to my friends on the republican side you may own the field right now, but you won't own it forever. And I pray God when the Democrats take back control we don't make the kind of naked power grab you are doing. Oops. And of course, Republicans are just as bad. Nearly all of them love the idea of the nuclear option in 2005. But today, they bark about it, saying it is going to destroy the Senate. That is a switch. Now, as an aside, the only senator to oppose the nuclear option in 2005 and oppose it now is Senator John McCain. But here's my point. It's insulting that the politicians think that we are that dumb. We heard what both sides said last time. I hate to say it, but they are a bunch of phonies. That's my "Off the Record" comment tonight.
